awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Incorporating SPECFEM3D numerical seismograms in the Global CMT Project
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will lay the groundwork for improvements in the scientific description of earthquakes, benefitting researchers in earthquake statistics, seismic tomography, seismic hazard, and seismic discrimination, as well as tectonic interpretation and analysis. This is the first step towards making the results of complex and expensive numerical calculations available for multiple applications and a wide range of users. This work focuses on demonstrating the feasibility of the methodology, but the database and method will be valuable for any research requiring accurate predictions of the global seismic wavefield from an arbitrary earthquake at any location without expensive computation. Two graduate students will be trained in research at the nexus of earthquake science, theoretical seismology, and computational Earth science.

This two-year, focused effort will (1) develop a new method for calculating, storing, and accessing high-fidelity long-period synthetic seismograms for state-of-the-art 3D tomographic models of the Earth, and (2) incorporate these seismograms in the earthquake analysis of the Global Centroid-Moment-Tensor (CMT) Project. Currently, the CMT synthetic seismograms are calculated using modern 3D Earth models, but accuracy is limited by the validity of the path-average approximation for mode summation and surface-wave ray theory, inexact predictions of the amplitude and polarization of ground motion, and other unmodeled effects, bias retrieved earthquake parameters. The incorporation of higher-fidelity synthetic seismograms in the CMT analysis will improve the characterization of seismic sources and remove concerns about a key source of uncertainty and bias. The team will adapt the spectral-element wave-equation solver SPECFEM3D_GLOBE to generate a database of kernel seismograms on a global grid of hypocenters, for a large set of station locations, using source-receiver reciprocity to speed up the calculation. Kernel seismograms on the grid will be organized and stored in a format that facilitates rapid access to a particular source region and the stations of the Global Seismographic Network. Kernel seismograms for an arbitrary centroid location will be efficiently calculated by spatial interpolation, in a manner that matches the accuracy of the full forward calculation. The CMT code will be modified to ingest the interpolated SPECFEM3D_GLOBE seismograms and testing will allow the assessment of success of the approach and method. The Princeton numerical seismology group and Lamont earthquake-analysis group will jointly evaluate the approach and fidelity of the waveform interpolation, develop practical formats for accessing the (massive) database of global waveforms, and assess the success of these developments.

This project is jointly supported by the Geophysics and Instrumentation and Facilities programs in the Division of Earth Sciences. It is also co-funded by a collaboration between the Directorate for Geosciences and Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure to support AI/ML and open science activities in the geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Global Centroid Moment Tensor (GCMT) project strives to provide the seismology community with the most complete, comprehensive catalog of global strain release. The results, GCMTs, are used for many studies, from seismic risk and hazard analysis to global tomography. However, while the GCMTs are a robust product and fit the observed data well, the delivered source parameters suffer from the approximate nature of the three-dimensional (3-D) forward modeling in the inversion. 

Our mission was to remove the key uncertainty of approximate forward modeling from the GCMT analysis by implementing a global database of 3-D Green functions. The pre-computation of 3-D Green functions has been achieved at the regional scale but comes with its own challenges at the global scale. The core development in this project was the augmentation of the widely used global, spectral-element seismic wavefield forward modeling software specfem3d_globe to store the wavefield on a ``seismologically’’ selected submesh of spectral elements. We thereby keep the seismic wavefield discretization in the form of Lagrange polynomials and do not lose any fidelity compared to brute force forward modeling, when storing the seismic wavefield. 

The subselection of elements is a crucial component that enables the permanent storage of a global database of 3-D Green functions. It has been common for regional databases to store the wavefield in the form of the six-element strain, a discontinuous field, for each spectral element separately to reduce interpolation errors. However, the spectral-element method is naturally based on the continuous three-component displacement wavefield, which can be differentiated at extraction time and restore the strain. As a result, the storage of the continuous displacement wavefield significantly reduces the required storage compared to strain databases, cutting it to less than half.

We computed two global Green function databases at different temporal resolutions but at the same sampling rate and duration, 4s and 4h, respectively. The 34s database from the model GLAD-M25 resulted in 130 Terabytes (TB) of storage, and the 17s database using model GLAD-M35 resulted in 250 TB. The fact that the database is not even doubling in size results from the subselection scheme, which only considers spectral elements containing a GCMT event before 2023 and their neighbor element. This is key to its potential practicality as a routine tool.

To showcase the capability of the GLAD-M25 database and the efficiency of database extraction over brute force forward computation of the 3-D Green function, we inverted for the source parameters of ~9,000 earthquakes without limiting iterations. The results reveal a significant reduction in events with non-double-couple components, particularly for deep events. This underscores the impact of the updated upper mantle from model GLAD-M35 and the effect of unmodeled 3-D path effects of approximate methods on the resulting source parameters. 

Finally, we integrated the 3-D seismograms into the GCMT analysis by implementing extraction tools for regional subsets of the database. The reduction in waveform misfit between the observed data and the synthetic, extracted seismograms is astonishing, confirming our predictions that the model and 3-D path effects significantly impact the resulting source parameters and synthetic seismograms. In summary, the global 3-D Green function database now allows us to systematically assess the impact of approximate 3-D forward modeling methods on the resulting source parameters and to include 3-D synthetic seismograms in routine applications.
